importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The outbreak in the DRC was declared on this date, marking the official start of the current Ebola outbreak in the country.
The last new case of Ebola was identified on this date, signaling a potential end to active transmission.
The final patient was discharged on this date, marking a key milestone in ending the outbreak.
A 42-day countdown to officially declare the outbreak over began on this date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 42-day period from September 26 to October 21 is the critical window during which no new cases must be detected to officially end the outbreak.

keyTakeAways: The last known Ebola patient in the DRC has been discharged from a treatment centre in Bulape, Kasai province, marking a major milestone in controlling the outbreak.
This is the 19th recovery out of 64 total cases (53 confirmed and 11 probable) since the outbreak began on September 4, 2025.
No new cases have been reported since September 25, 2025, which has allowed health officials to initiate a 42-day countdown to officially declare the outbreak over.
The outbreak, which began in the remote Bulape and Mweka areas of Kasai province, is the DRC’s 16th recorded Ebola outbreak to date.
The DRC's robust public health response, supported by the World Health Organization (WHO) and partners, was critical in containing the virus.
A 32-bed treatment centre was established in Bulape for the first time outside a simulation, and over 35,000 people have received vaccinations in the area.
The remote location of Kasai province posed significant logistical challenges, but may have also limited virus spread.
Ebola is a highly lethal disease; without treatment, up to 90% of cases are fatal, and the largest outbreak occurred in West Africa (2014–2016) with over 28,000 infections and 11,325 deaths.
The DRC had previously experienced a single case in 2022, highlighting the ongoing risk of outbreaks in the region.

namedEntities.name: Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in Central Africa that has experienced multiple Ebola outbreaks, including the current one in Kasai province.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The DRC is the current location of the Ebola outbreak and is central to the narrative of containment and recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: Kasai province
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in the southwest of the DRC where the Ebola outbreak began in Bulape and Mweka areas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The remote and difficult-to-access nature of Kasai province made response efforts challenging but may have helped limit virus spread.

namedEntities.name: Bulape
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A location within Kasai province where the Ebola outbreak was first detected and where the final patient was discharged.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bulape is the site of the last patient's discharge and a key location in the outbreak's progression and containment.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WHO declared the outbreak, provided support, deployed teams, and coordinated the response in the DRC, playing a central role in the containment effort.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This historical context shows how severe and widespread Ebola outbreaks can be, emphasizing the importance of timely and effective responses like the one in the DRC.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It reflects the ongoing vulnerability of the DRC to Ebola and serves as a background for understanding the current outbreak's significance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The last Ebola patient in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has been discharged from a treatment centre in Bulape, Kasai province, marking a major breakthrough in the country's ongoing outbreak. This is the 19th recovery out of 64 total cases since the outbreak began on September 4, 2025, with no new cases reported since September 25. The World Health Organization (WHO) and local partners played a critical role in containing the virus through the establishment of a 32-bed treatment centre and over 35,000 vaccinations in the area. With no new cases detected for 42 days, the outbreak is set for official declaration as over. The remote location of Kasai province posed significant challenges, but may have limited virus spread. This event is significant globally as it demonstrates the effectiveness of coordinated public health responses to contain a high-fatality disease like Ebola.
title: Last Ebola patient discharged in DR Congo, WHO says
